webTitle: Service sector growth cools, pointing to overall slowdown

fields.bodyText: The pace of growth in the service sector has cooled over the summer, suggesting momentum in the overall economy could ease in the second half of the year. Consumer-focused firms such as hotels, bars and travel firms experienced their weakest expansion in a year, according to the CBI, with a balance of 25% more firms saying activity was up on last month compared with those recording a fall. Business and professional services such as accountancy, law and marketing grew at the slowest pace since November. But the CBI emphasised the mood of optimism in the overall sector, which accounts for about 78% of the economy, pointing out that lawyers, accountants and marketing specialists were being hired in the greatest numbers since before the financial crisis. In its latest snapshot of the UK services sector, the business lobby group reported that business and professional service firms are feeling more confident about the economy, although almost half are concerned that skills shortages will cramp their expansion plans in the year ahead. According to the CBI's survey of 215 firms, 44% of professional services firms said head count was up on the previous three months, while 11% said it was down. The 33% positive balance means that employment has been growing at its fastest pace since November 2007. These employers said they expect hiring to accelerate during the next quarter, putting expectations for employment growth at 46%, the highest since 1998 when the survey began. But 45% of these firms fear that shortages of professional staff will limit their expansion in the year ahead. Consumer-focused businesses were also upbeat about the economic climate, with 48% saying they were more optimistic than three months ago and only 4% less optimistic. A net total of 12% expect employment to go up in the next quarter. These firms also reported plans for record spending on their businesses: a net total of 16% expect to invest in land or buildings, the highest since 2010; while spending on vehicles and machinery is set to be at a record high - 29% of consumer firms have investment plans in this area. A total of 43% of firms in consumer-facing industries said business was better than three months ago, while 17% reported that takings were down. The resulting 25% balance is well above average, but the slowest point of growth since August 2013. Katja Hall, CBI deputy director general, said: "The slowing in the pace of growth and profits in the service sector reflects our view that momentum in the economy will ease in the second half of the year. "Employing more staff and planning to increase investment are positive steps in the quest for sustainable growth. However, skills shortages mean it is increasingly hard for firms to find and hire the right people. It's important that business and government address this issue together, to put the economy of the future on the right footing." The latest service sector survey comes after manufacturers reported that wages are rising faster than any other part of the economy. The engineering and manufacturing employers' association EEF reported that pay rose by 2.6% on last year at a time when wage growth has been at a near standstill. At the weekend the Bank of England deputy governor Ben Broadbent said UK workers may not see growth in their pay packets any any time soon.

webTitle: Olive oil prices set to rise sharply after Andalusia drought

fields.bodyText: Hold the bruschetta: olive oil prices are expected to rise sharply after a prolonged drought in the world's biggest producing region in southern Spain, at the same time as a blight has hit the crop in Puglia, Italy's main olive-growing area. While there is still time for rain to save the day in Andalusia, as harvesting takes place from October to January depending on the olive variety and location, without better weather soon this year's crop is predicted to be 40% down on the bumper 1.77 million-tonne harvest of 2013-14. "Not even the most optimistic are predicting a million tonnes," said David Erice of Spain's Small Farmers Union. "We're expecting something closer to 2012, when production was around 700,000 tonnes." Spain produces 50% of the world's olive oil, with 73% of that coming from the province of Andalusia in the south and 16% from Catalonia in the north-east. In 2013 olive oil exports from Andalusia were worth €1.5bn (£1.1bn). The drought isn't the only problem. Bumper harvests leave the trees exhausted, said Erice, and they produce far fewer olives the following year. Anticipation of a poor harvest means that in the wholesale market, where it is priced per kg, virgin olive oil has already risen from €2.40 to €2.70 per kg over the past few weeks, according to Infaoliva, the Spanish olive oil federation. The drought in 2012 led to a 13% price rise. Prices are predicted to rise by as much as €0.50c a litre – although extra virgin olive oil retails in supermarkets at around €3.00 a litre in Spain and is a popular loss leader in supermarket wars, to the detriment of producers who in recent years have complained that supermarkets have pushed the price down to below the cost of production. Some analysts predict that supermarkets will absorb any price hike in order to maintain their competitive edge. Virgin olive oil futures for September are at their highest level since June 2013, and some suppliers say that speculators are contributing to the rise in futures prices by capitalising on the uncertainty caused by the drought. The bets they are making are driving prices higher. There are also claims that some producers are withholding stock in anticipation of selling at a higher price later in the year. However, for all but the biggest producers the olive oil business has become a no-win proposition. If the harvest is good, the price slumps; a poor harvest means selling much less for only slightly more. The oil is exported principally to France, Portugal and Italy. Italy often repackages Spanish oil as "estate bottled", giving consumers the impression that it is an Italian product. Italy is the second largest producer after Spain, accounting for 15% of world production, with Greece producing 13%. This year Spain has overtaken Italy as the market leader in olive oil in the US and Japan. Worldwide demand for "liquid gold" has risen by 60% over the past 20 years, driven by increased demand in China, the US, Canada and Australia. Olive oil has been left off the list of agricultural products embargoed by Russia in its ongoing spat with the European Union. "If Russia had included it in the list of banned products it would have been a great setback," says Rafael Picó of Asoliva, the oil exporters' association. While it is drought that threatens the Spanish harvest, in the southern Italian olive-growing region of Puglia the trees have been afflicted by the bacteria Xylella fastidiosa. "There is no cure. The only solution is to burn the infected trees to stop the bacteria spreading quickly," Raffaele Piano, a local grower, said. "Prices will rise by 30% to 40% but quality will not be affected," he said. While harvests in other major producing countries such as Greece and Turkey are expected to be at average levels this year, they will not be able to make up for the shortfall in Spanish production, and price rises seem inevitable.

webTitle: Co-op members warned management shakeup may not go far enough

fields.bodyText: As members of the Co-Operative Group prepare to vote on sweeping changes to the way the troubled chain of supermarkets, chemists and funeral homes is managed, they have already been warned that the proposed shakeup may not go far enough. In an attempt to turn the corner after a disastrous period when the Co-op slumped to its biggest ever loss of £2.5bn, members are being asked to vote on Saturday on a radical new structure that will ensure the board has a majority of independent members. The proposals unveiled earlier this month would cut the size of the Co-op board from 18 members to 11, with an independent chair and five independent non-executives. Overseeing the board would be a council of 100 members, to act as a guardian of the group's values, while a senate would act as go-between to help all sides work together. But in a watering down of recommendations from city veteran Lord Myners, three democratically elected members would remain on the board. Myners, a former Labour City minister, who was brought in to overhaul governance, wanted the board to be purged of all elected members. He argued that the current crop of elected directors – which includes a plasterer and a university lecturer – lack business experience and failed to stop the group embarking on some "breathtakingly value-destructive" deals, such as the takeover of the Somerfield supermarket chain and the Britannia building society. In other respects, the Co-op plan mostly follows Lord Myners's recommendations, and he has described the Co-op proposals as "significant progress". Oliver Parry, corporate governance adviser at the Institute of Directors, said the proposals were a step in the right direction but that the Co-op would still have "a convoluted structure" that would not meet the standards expected of a plc. Parry said: "We have to understand that the Co-op is a mutual, so it is a slightly different beast to other organisations. But the one area of concern is the fact that three of members will be elected by other members, so it is not an entirely independent board. "For us, from a governance perspective, without that thorough independence once has to ask how much independent oversight they can actually exercise." Co-op members will vote on the proposals on Saturday 30 August, with the result expected to be announced on the same day. Nearly four-fifths of the votes are held by Co-op members, represented by seven regional boards. The remaining 21% of the vote is held by 127 independent societies. The Co-op's members voted in favour of the broad outline of reform in May, but this is the first time they will get a say on the detailed plans, which the Co-op's management hopes will end the group's rescue phase. The Co-op Group, which now employs 87,000 people since losing majority control of the Co-op bank to hedge funds, is due to publish half-year results on 4 September. Simon Burke, a non-executive director at the Co-op, who is bidding to join the new board, told the Guardian earlier this month it was important to keep democratically elected members to make sure the Co-op's values "translate through in how it does business". Ursula Lidbetter, the Co-op's chair, has stressed that only people with "business acumen and commitment to cooperative values and principles" would be chosen to serve on the board. Parry said "it's wait and see" whether this would be the case. "The Co-op has obviously got to learn from their mistakes of the past and what we have said to members is that they have to look very, very closely at the proposals and decide is that going to do enough to avoid the kind of difficulties that the Co-op have faced in the past." Co-operative Group: a timeline 2000 Co-operative Wholesale Society merges with Co-operative Retail Services, and the Co-operative Group is created. A group structure is agreed. 2007 Co-op Group merges with its biggest cooperative rival, United Co-operative. United's ambitious boss, Peter Marks, becomes chief executive of the new merged organisation. 2009 Co-op pays £1.6bn to take over supermarket chain Somerfield. The Co-operative Bank and Britannia building society agree a merger, under Neville Richardson. July 2011 Richardson quits with £4.6m, following a restructuring that sheds 670 financial adviser jobs. Barry Tootell takes over. August 2011 Co-op announces a bid for 632 Lloyds branches, Project Verde. December 2011 Lloyds board approves the Co-op bid. Privately, City regulator warns Lloyds that Co-op lacks the reserves to underwrite the deal. March 2013 Co-op Bank blames Britannia for a £257m loss in 2012. Co-op's insurance and asset management businesses are lined up for sale. April 2013 Co-op withdraws offer for Lloyds branches, blaming the economy and "regulatory requirements". May 2013 Moody's downgrades bank's credit rating to junk and Tootell resigns. B&Q boss Euan Sutherland takes over as Co-op chief executive. A £1.5bn black hole is found in the Co-op Bank's reserves. June 2013 The Rev Paul Flowers steps down as chairman of the Co-op Bank. October 2013 Co-op hands bondholders control of the bank to seal a rescue. Co-op left with 30% stake. 6 November 2013 Flowers shows limited grasp of the banking business under questioning by Treasury select committee about failure of the Lloyds deal. 17 November 2013 The Mail on Sunday publishes a video showing Flowers arranging to buy drugs. 12 December 2013 Co-op hires former City minister Lord Myners to review its operations for £1 salary. 11 March 2014 Sutherland resigns after his £6.6m pay deal is leaked to the Observer. He brands Co-op "ungovernable". 14 March 2014 Myners warns that Co-op could go bust unless it urgently reforms board and voting structure. He outlines a plan to replace multi-layered hierarchy with a plc-type board, and denounces "bullying" tactics from Co-Op activists. 24 March 2014 Co-op Bank reveals losses for 2013 could be as high as £1.3bn. 7 April 2014 Co-op Bank delays full-year financial results until 11 April. 9 April 2014 Myners quits over increasing opposition to his plans. He will, however, complete his review. 7 May 2014 Flowers pleads guilty to drugs possession charges and is ordered to pay £525. 8 May 2014 Co-op Group's stake in Co-op bank falls to around 20%, as the bank turns to investors to raise £400m fresh capital. 17 May 2014 Co-op Group members vote unanimously to accept an overhaul of the 150-year old organisation, although a further vote on the exact detail of the changes must be held at the end of the summer. 22 August 2014 Co-op Bank announces half-year losses of £75.8m and says it will face further losses this year and next. • This article was amended on 29 August 2014. An earlier version said: "The biggest electors, with four-fifths of the vote, are seven regional cooperatives, of which Midcounties and Midlands are the largest. The remaining 21% of the vote is held by 127 independent societies." In fact nearly four-fifths of the vote is held by Co-op members, represented by seven regional boards; the Midlands Co-op merged with the Anglia Co-op to form the Central England Co-op last year; and the Midcounties and Central England are two of the 127 independent societies. The article also previously said that the current crop of elected directors of the Co-operative Group includes a nurse; in fact the nurse in question, Steven Bayes, lost his place on the board in April.

webTitle: Retirement and age pension reform needs to be fairer and more equal

fields.standfirst: Reforms are necessary to make pension spending sustainable, but the government’s changes are unequal and ignore the growing cost of superannuation tax concessions for the wealthy
fields.body:
Among the decisions in the budget that have met with little joy from voters were the proposed changes to the age pension. A paper released last week by the progressive thinktank, Per Capita, argues that the current system is skewed in favour of the wealthy and that the measures introduced in the budget will only serve to skew this further.

While there is a need to address the issue of the ageing population, and the increasing cost of the age pension it needs to be done in both a sustainable and equitable manner.

The problem as noted by Emily Millane in her Per Capita report, The Entitlement of Age, however is that the government’s response to the growing outlays of the age pension was to hurt everyone receiving a pension rather than attempt to make it more targeted and equal.

In the May budget, the government proposed changing the indexation of the pension to merely being indexed to the Consumer Price Index (CPI) rather than the highest of the male average full-time weekly earnings, the Pensioner and Beneficiary Cost of Living Index (PBCLI), or CPI.

The Parliamentary Budget Office last week released a report which suggested such a change would see the cost of the pension reduced by $6.9bn in 2024-25:

As the PBCLI and male wage generally rises faster than the CPI, households dependent on the age pension would fall further into relative poverty under this change:

The Per Capita report notes that the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia (ASFA) defines retirement lifestyle in a couple ways. A “comfortable lifestyle” would see retirees able to “be involved in a broad range of leisure and recreational activities” and be able to purchase such things as “household goods, private health insurance, a reasonable car, good clothes, a range of electronic equipment, and domestic and occasionally international holiday travel.”

A “modest retirement lifestyle” would be one “better than the Age Pension, but still only able to afford fairly basic activities” – which does not include new technology products.

ASFA estimates the minimum per week required to achieve a modest standard of living in retirement is $448 for singles and $645 for couples. This also assumes retirees own their home outright. Thus, it is fairly sobering to note that the current maximum age pension payment per week is $383 for singles and $577 for couples.

Reducing the indexation below the cost of living of pensioners to the CPI will only exacerbate this gap between what the pension provides and what is classed as a “modest retirement lifestyle”.

One of the problems with funding an increase in the pension is not only are we living longer, we’re living longer than we were expected to live. A woman born in 1938 was expected to live 74 years, but the average age of death for women in 2012 (74 years on from 1938) is 80:

The Gillard government responded to this by increasing the retirement age to 67, and Tony Abbott and Joe Hockey have further proposed it being increased to 70, although the changes proposed by Hockey won’t affect anyone born before 1965 – thus exempting all baby boomers.

Per Capita notes that increasing this age hurts those who work in lower paying, more physical occupations: “the sort of jobs people are likely to stay in longer are managerial and professional jobs, whereas very few people in sales, community work or machinery operation work to a later age”.

Indeed, the ABS data shows that while managers and professionals make up 29% of the workforce, they constitute 46% of those who retired after the age of 70. Labourers on the other hand make up 13% of the workforce, but 21% of those who retire before the age of 55.

Per Capita argues exemptions should be made for people “who cannot continue to work because of factors like age discrimination, or due to the nature of their work.”

The report suggests that the pension needs to be better means tested. Currently the family home is excluded from the assets test. There can be issues with valuing family homes – for example with the differing values in differing areas. Instead it recommends continuing to exclude the family home, but reducing the asset-free amount – the amount of assets you can have before it affects your pension – for homeowners from $202,000 for singles and $286,500 for couples to $100,000 and $150,000 respectively.

It also recommends that the government provide loans at the 10 year bond rate to those who were excluded from receiving the pension under the new means test up to the value of the pension they would have received. The loan would be repaid out of money from the sale of their estate.

But as many critics of the budget have noted, retirement policy is not just about the pension, but also superannuation.

Per capita found that while the superannuation system does lighten the load of the pension system it massively favours those on higher incomes. It notes that “over 50% of superannuation tax concessions are paid to Australia’s top 20% of income earners.” The report also says “the public cost of superannuation concessions will be $42.4bn in 2015-2016, by which stage these concessions will cost the government more than the age pension”.

But interestingly rather than viewing this as a bonus, the report found that “people on higher incomes have come to regard superannuation concessions as an entitlement.

There is a significant correlation between people’s incomes and their belief that retirement incomes should be increased though more tax concessions. Similarly, people are more likely to believe age pension should be increased if they earn less income:

Thus far the higher income lobby group has been more persuasive. The Abbott government has proposed abolishing the low income superannuation contribution for people earning less than $37,000 – meaning the tax on such people’s superannuation contribution would go from 0% to 15%. It also announced it will not proceed with the superannuation concession reduction – which would have seen the superannuation contributions of people earning over $300,000 be taxed at 30% rather than 15%.

And finally, the government is not going ahead with the proposed taxation on superannuation assets which provide an income of $100,000 and above.

Rather than a flat 15% tax for everyone, the Per Capita report recommends taxing superannuation contributions for those earning $80,0001-$180,000 at the marginal tax rate less 5% (32%), and for those earning over $180,000 at the full marginal tax rate (45%).

Such a move would certainly make the system more equitable, and less costly to government. It also is one the government needs to consider to overcome the rightful impression that the budget hurt the poorest hardest. As treasury secretary, Dr Martin Parkinson, said in a speech last week on the selling of the budget, “perhaps it could have been clearer to say that everybody is going to contribute, this is the budget dimension of it and there will be more coming with the tax white paper.”

Given the impact of this budget there certainly does need to be more to come to demonstrate this government is at all concerned about redressing inequality.
fields.bodyText: Among the decisions in the budget that have met with little joy from voters were the proposed changes to the age pension. A paper released last week by the progressive thinktank, Per Capita, argues that the current system is skewed in favour of the wealthy and that the measures introduced in the budget will only serve to skew this further. While there is a need to address the issue of the ageing population, and the increasing cost of the age pension it needs to be done in both a sustainable and equitable manner. The problem as noted by Emily Millane in her Per Capita report, The Entitlement of Age, however is that the government’s response to the growing outlays of the age pension was to hurt everyone receiving a pension rather than attempt to make it more targeted and equal. In the May budget, the government proposed changing the indexation of the pension to merely being indexed to the Consumer Price Index (CPI) rather than the highest of the male average full-time weekly earnings, the Pensioner and Beneficiary Cost of Living Index (PBCLI), or CPI. A “comfortable lifestyle” would see retirees able to “be involved in a broad range of leisure and recreational activities” and be able to purchase such things as “household goods, private health insurance, a reasonable car, good clothes, a range of electronic equipment, and domestic and occasionally international holiday travel.” A “modest retirement lifestyle” would be one “better than the Age Pension, but still only able to afford fairly basic activities” – which does not include new technology products. ASFA estimates the minimum per week required to achieve a modest standard of living in retirement is $448 for singles and $645 for couples. This also assumes retirees own their home outright. Thus, it is fairly sobering to note that the current maximum age pension payment per week is $383 for singles and $577 for couples. Reducing the indexation below the cost of living of pensioners to the CPI will only exacerbate this gap between what the pension provides and what is classed as a “modest retirement lifestyle”. One of the problems with funding an increase in the pension is not only are we living longer, we’re living longer than we were expected to live. A woman born in 1938 was expected to live 74 years, but the average age of death for women in 2012 (74 years on from 1938) is 80: The Gillard government responded to this by increasing the retirement age to 67, and Tony Abbott and Joe Hockey have further proposed it being increased to 70, although the changes proposed by Hockey won’t affect anyone born before 1965 – thus exempting all baby boomers. Labourers on the other hand make up 13% of the workforce, but 21% of those who retire before the age of 55. Instead it recommends continuing to exclude the family home, but reducing the asset-free amount – the amount of assets you can have before it affects your pension – for homeowners from $202,000 for singles and $286,500 for couples to $100,000 and $150,000 respectively. fields.headline: Retirement and age pension reform needs to be fairer and more equal
fields.trailText: Reforms are necessary to make pension spending sustainable, but the government’s changes are unequal and ignore the growing cost of superannuation tax concessions for the wealthy

webTitle: Switzerland's Roche agrees to buy US biotech company InterMune

fields.standfirst: Multibillion-dollar consolidation of global pharmaceutical sector continues with another blockbuster
fields.body:
The multibillion-dollar consolidation of the global pharmaceutical sector has seen another blockbuster deal after Switzerland's Roche agreed to buy US biotech company InterMune for $8.3bn (£5bn).

Roche, which makes influenza drug Tamiflu, said the deal would "allow Roche to broaden and strengthen its respiratory portfolio globally".

California-based InterMune focuses its work on the deadly lung disease idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.

Firms that make products for treating rare or incurable conditions, dubbed orphan drugs, have become a target for big drugmakers because the drugs are highly profitable.

The pharmaceutical industry has seen escalating merger and acquisition activity this year, with FTSE 100-listed Shire agreeing to a £32bn takeover by AbbVie of the US and Britain's GlaxoSmithKline engaging in a multibillion-pound asset swap with Novartis.

US group Pfizer attempted to buy the UK's second largest drugs firm, AstraZeneca, in a £69bn deal that foundered in the face of political pressure and AstraZeneca's refusal to do a deal.

So far this year deals worth $260bn have been arranged in the pharmaceutical, biotech and medical product sectors, according to figures from Mergermarket.
